awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Solar Neutrino Science with Borexino: The Quest for CNO Neutrinos
awd_abstract_narration:
Solar neutrino research has already discovered massive neutrinos and flavor mixing and is moving into an era where precision measurements can provide a unique probe of the structure and composition of the Sun. The carbon-nitrogen-oxygen (CNO) cycle is one of the fusion reactions by which stars convert hydrogen to helium, releasing electron-neutrinos. The CNO neutrino flux depends on the abundance of carbon in the core of the Sun. A measurement of the CNO flux would be the first direct measurement of the solar metallicity (the abundance of elements other than hydrogen or helium) in the core of the Sun. It could test the fundamental assumption of homogeneity in the Sun and provide crucial information regarding opacities in the solar interior that are important for helioseismology. Such studies could thus have a great impact on our understanding of the Sun, stellar astrophysics, the link between planetary and stellar formation, as well as basic neutrino physics. Borexino is a liquid scintillator detector, located at the Gran Sasso National Laboratory in Italy, with a unique sensitivity to solar neutrinos.

The Borexino research program has involved many undergraduate and graduate students. Mentoring and training young researchers at the collaborating institutions and other schools has always been a high priority. The three groups will continue to involve undergraduate students in this research and disseminate research to the broader community.

The research funded here plans to measure neutrinos from the catalytic reactions on 12-C and 15-N which convert four protons to 4-He, producing neutrinos from the beta decays of 13-N and 15-O. The CN neutrino flux depends directly on the abundance of 12-C and 15-N in the core of the Sun, and their measurement would be the first direct measurement of the metallicity (elements heavier than 4-He), in the core of the Sun. This result will be far reaching because the solar composition is the basis for many important topics in astrophysics, including stellar structure, stellar evolution, and stellar atmospheres, to name a few. In addition, it will address the 'solar composition problem', the apparent disagreement in metallicity determined from recent advances in analysis of solar photospheric optical spectra, which favors a low metallicity, and advances in helioseismology, which favors high metallicity. Since modifications of the Standard Solar Model to explain a non-uniform solar composition have not been very successful, the 'solar composition problem' remains an unexplained flaw in the Standard Solar Model.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported the participation of the University of Massachusetts, Amherst group to the final phase of the Borexino solar neutrino experiment, between 2019 and 2023. Borexino is a large detector that used 300 tons of organic liquid (called scintillator) to detect neutrinos via flashes of light emitted when they interact with the liquid’s electrons. It operated at the underground Gran Sasso laboratory in Italy between 2007 and 2021. The PI was involved with the project since 1998, played a central part in designing, building and commissioning the apparatus, and received NSF funding to extract science from its data since 2009.
From 2007 until 2016, Borexino measured the fluxes of neutrinos emitted along the sequence of nuclear fusion reactions and beta decays making up the solar the pp-chain, by which hydrogen is spent to produce helium releasing about 99% of the energy output of the Sun. Nuclear fusion processes keep the Sun in the state of thermal equilibrium we observe today and prevents its matter from gravitationally collapse on itself. In a decade-long sequence of measurements, Borexino detected Beryllium-7, pp, and pep solar neutrinos for the first time via the district energy signature of each. Ever more precise measurements culminated in the paper “Simultaneous precision spectroscopy of pp, Be-7, and pep solar neutrinos with Borexino Phase-II”, Phys Rev D 100, 082004 (2019).
What made the Borexino measurements possible was the quasi-total elimination of radioactivity within the Borexino scintillator, achieved using novel ultra-low background techniques that reduced the number of unwanted radioactive decays within the central 100 tons of scintillator to fewer than a couple of tens per day. For reference, the number of decays from radon and its products within a typical, well-ventilated room in a US home is on the order of a few hundred per second.
Through this award, the UMass group together with US collaborators at Virginia Tech and Princeton University (lead institution), played a crucial role in making the first measurement of the solar neutrinos emitted in the so-called CNO cycle, a sequence of reactions catalyzed by the presence of Carbon, Nitrogen, and Oxygen in the Sun’s core plasma that fuse hydrogen into helium alongside the pp-chain. The detection of CNO neutrinos in Borexino was extremely challenging because of the presence of environmental radioactive decays whose fingerprint in the detector is very similar to the CNO energy spectrum. These are Carbon-11, produced by high energy cosmic rays traversing the detector, and Bismuth-210, a beta-emitter produced in the decays of long-lived Lead-210 in the lower part of the Radon-222 decay chain. Since radon is naturally present in air, its decay products are known to deposit onto exposed surfaces. Despite having built the thin, 8.5-meter diameter nylon containment vessel inside a radon-suppressed clean room, a tiny, yet measurable amount of Bi-210 was present on its inner surface in contact with the Borexino scintillator.
Techniques to identify C-11 decays and filter them from the data were developed and progressively refined for previous measurements. The same techniques recently led to the related paper “Novel techniques for alpha/beta pulse shape discrimination in Borexino”, arXiv:2310.11826, currently under review. Even when selecting only event in the inner-most volume of scintillators, thus cutting out the contaminated edge surfaces, Bi-210 found its way to the center of the detector via convective currents triggered by seasonal temperature inversions in the detector that followed ventilation pattern in the laboratory. Through previous NSF funding, Borexino was thermally insulated and the experimental Hall temperature controlled between 2016 and 2019 to stabilize the Borexino fluids. The sensitivity of Borexino to measuring CNO neutrinos was reported in “Sensitivity to neutrinos from the solar CNO cycle in Borexino ”, Eur. Phys. J. C 80, 1091 (2020) and the hoped-for result was achieved and the detection of CNO neutrinos was reported in “Experimental evidence of neutrinos produced in the CNO fusion cycle in the Sun”, Nature 587, 577 (2020), followed by a refined measurement as per “Improved Measurement of Solar Neutrinos from the Carbon-Nitrogen-Oxygen Cycle by Borexino and Its Implications for the Standard Solar Model”, Phys. Rev. Lett 129, 252701 (2021).
With the proposed solar program completed, Borexino also demonstrated that information about the incoming direction of solar neutrinos is carried over to the direction in which the scintillation light is emitted (“Correlated and integrated directionality for sub-MeV solar neutrinos in Borexino”, Phys Rev D 105, 052002 (2022)). The technique was demonstrated with Be-7 neutrinos in “First Directional Measurement of Sub-MeV Solar Neutrinos with Borexino”, Phys Rev Lett, 128 091803 (2022). Directional information was included to improve, yet again, the CNO neutrino measurement, as reported in “Final results of Borexino on CNO solar neutrinos”, Phys. Rev D, 108 102005 (2023).
